text: What breaks me every time in this story is that moment they say Libby had the presence of mind to pull out her phone and record the man walking toward them. A 14-year-old kid staring down real danger and thinking clearly enough to capture the one piece of evidence the world would cling to for years. That clip is probably the last thing she ever did, and somehow it became the only voice those girls had left to point at the truth. When you look at everything that followed ‚Äî the chaos, the suspects, the infighting, the town tearing itself apart ‚Äî it feels like the one thing that never changes is that grainy image of a man on a bridge who still hasn‚Äôt been definitively proven to be anyone. If you had to bet on just one detail in this whole timeline that actually holds the key, which moment do you think it is?

text:
It‚Äôs Richard Allen‚Äôs Google searches. Compliments of FOX 59 - On Oct. 2, 2022, less than two weeks before he was initially questioned in the case, Allen searched for the ‚Äú65+ best kidnapping and hostage movies ever made.‚Äù Other searches from the same day included ‚Äúman held hostage by teen‚Äù and ‚Äúmovie about a man being held against his will.‚Äù

On Oct. 17, 2022, he searched ABC News for an article about the Delphi murders. That would have been four days after investigators initially questioned him about the case. On May 27, 2020, he searched for a story about rebuilding the Monon High Bridge. In May 2021, he searched for shooting ranges.

Allen also searched multiple times about the Delphi case, according to the records. On Aug. 4 and Aug. 5, 2022, he did five searches for ‚ÄúDelphi murders update.‚Äù That‚Äôs just a couple months before he found himself at the center of the case. Between January 2022 and April 2022, Allen did a general search for ‚ÄúDelphi‚Äù 11 times.  Also in April 2022, he searched ‚Äúshould I die now?‚Äù

It appeared Allen had an interest in disturbing movies. On April 27, 2022, he searched for ‚Äúinsidious‚Äù and ‚Äúhorrifying‚Äù things to watch. In another search from June 2023, he looked for the ‚Äúmost f*** up thing to watch on Netflix,‚Äù according to the analysis.

text:
In the beginnng you hear: In Delphi everybody knows everybody. In the middle you hear: Nobody ever heard of Richard Allen. As far as I understand, he lived and worked in Delphi through all those years. And now they all say: It's his stature, it's his voice. Richard Allen made one big mistake: He contacted the police and told them about his presence on the bridge one day after the disappearance. If he hadn't done that he would never have been caught and indicted.

One of the big problems in the investigation seems to have been the processing of information. It was much too slow. One would hope that with the advent of AI they find a way to speed up this process of evaluating and classifying tips.

text:
If there were witnesses, you‚Äôd think there would be a lineup for them to choose the suspect from once authorities thought they found their guy (five years later). 
This case was absolutely horrifying to me when I first heard of it a few months after it happened. So I‚Äôve wanted nothing more than for them to find whoever did this horrific crime. And as much as I want their murderer to be caught and put away for the remainder of their life for killing two innocent babies, I‚Äôm not convinced 100% they have the right person. I still pray for this entire case, especially for the families of Abby and Libby. But now I also pray for true justice to prevail & for them to not have an innocent man behind bars. I‚Äôve grown up in small towns and I‚Äôve seen how innocent folks get blamed and messed up for life when law enforcement desperately needs to catch a ‚Äúkiller‚Äù or ‚Äúkillers‚Äù. 
The West Memphis Three were convicted of murdering three young boys & how they got the conviction was from a ‚Äúconfession‚Äù of one of the three teen ‚Äúsuspects‚Äù. Law enforcement did a great job convincing the area that these teens were guilty too, only for the truth to be revealed years later that their confession was a coerced confession from someone who didn‚Äôt have the mental capacity to be interrogated without representation in the room. They spoon fed that boy information about the crime scene and he only confessed to the information they gave him to work with and because he had been in there for hours & he wanted to go home. He was convinced the only way he could go home was if he told them what they wanted him to say. Now 30 years later, they‚Äôre finally out of prison but here again the good old boy system covered their butts by only agreeing to release them if they used the Alford plea. I would have signed that paper too if I was innocent and it was the only way to get freed, especially from death row. But my point is now anytime I hear about this case or any other case similar to it (such as this Delphi case), I can‚Äôt help but think ‚Äú the worst part is a killer has walked Scott free while more innocent people were dragged into these crimes and had to pay the price for the guilty‚Äù. 
I believe all of these could‚Äôve been solved if the authorities would‚Äôve swallowed their pride and got more experienced investigators to lead these cases. Jon Bonet Ramsey is another case I feel like should‚Äôve & could‚Äôve been solved if not for authorities big egos & refusal to get help from more experienced investigators. 
This is just my own opinion and above anything else, I pray for the victims families who have been left to pick up the very messy pieces of all of these cases. I wouldn‚Äôt wish this kind of pain on any living soul. üíî

They may truly have the killer of Abby and Libby. I don‚Äôt know. Richard Allen knows as well as God. But I have never heard of any man who hasn‚Äôt been convicted of a crime being housed in a prison until their trial. That‚Äôs utter bs. That‚Äôs terrifying in its own right. There‚Äôs no telling what he suffered during his stay before his trial & that‚Äôs why I do question the validity of his confessions. I did listen to them once they were released. Not one of them sounded as if he was speaking with mental clarity and truly trying to confess them to his wife. There were some that I thought ok, he sounds pretty much there in this one but the longer the phone call went on, the more I could tell he wasn‚Äôt all there. I‚Äôm not saying they weren‚Äôt damning to his case, but I find it funny that his wife still to this day stands behind him, not wavering on her stance that he was also coerced.  It just leaves room to doubt in my mind. 
But I can rest assured that Eventually, maybe not in this lifetime, but one day, will indeed be the day when all truth will be brought to light. Then the real judgement of the wicked and the guilty will prevail and all crimes against the innocent will be avenged. Until then, I do my best to be kind, and try to treat others like I want to be treated. 
Rip Abby & Libby. You truly deserved so much better. üïäÔ∏èü™Ω

text:
I wish people would stop saying when talking about a town, "everybody knows everybody", that's such a non statement. Firstly, how can everybody know everybody, walk down your own street, or your own unsealed road, if you live in a rural area. I lived in both & I'm 63 with a reasonably wide breadth of life experience, I worked, studied for 20 years, I wouldn't have time to get to know 'everybody' in my town. I could never claim to know everybody, in my own street, let alone my own town or suburb & if you do know people, how well do you actually know them? Richard Allen didn't get arrested for 5 years so he wasn't 'known'. 
Of course these situations are just horrifying that someone in someone's street has done such a terrible thing to someone's children for what, a fantasy they need to fullfill, we don't know who lives across the road let alone know everybody, it's impossible to know everybody or their inner secrets or what danger they can inflict in or on our Communities....

text: I‚Äôm gonna preface my comment with this - my gut feeling, which I have learned to trust throughout my life - is telling me that Richard Allen is not the killer. I have zero connection to that man, I‚Äôve been following this case since the day they didn‚Äôt come back to the pick up point, and being autistic and ADHD as well as having CPTSD, when I watch Richard Allen‚Äôs interrogation videos, when I listen to his ‚Äúconfessions‚Äù, when I watch him being walked into the courtroom etc., I get that feeling in my stomach like when you‚Äôre in line for a rollercoaster ride and you‚Äôre scared of heights, but you know you‚Äôre gonna ride it anyways. It is a feeling of dread, and it has been since the information started coming out after his arrest. When they first announced it, my first thought after seeing photos of Allen like his mugshot, I was dumbfounded. He looked nothing like the man in EITHER sketch! But if you TRULY dig and spend countless days hyper focused on this case, quietly educating yourself about this case and also learning to ‚Äúprofile‚Äù killers and think like an investigator (as much as I could via free resources on the internet), comparing evidence, statements, comparing and pouring over the questions asked by police, the info released and arrests, search warrants done by the police and doing the same by comparing what the FBI thought and wanted to do I wholeheartedly believe that you too would come to belief that Richard Allen is innocent. It makes me sick thinking of how this whole thing went down having a clear view of the entire picture. It makes me sick to think that justice hasn‚Äôt been served even a little bit. And THAT thought is where the feeling of dread comes from. Watching the trial and how little evidence they truly have on RA, and seeing that there‚Äôs truly more evidence to say that Ron Logan did it, and knowing that the prosecution has their mind made up and aren‚Äôt going to entertain any other suspect and wouldn‚Äôt allow any information related to the possible cult of odinism - didn‚Äôt even WANT to, coupled with their horrid mishandling of the entire case from the jump - ugh‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs appalling and makes me ashamed to be an Indiana native. Our justice system is broken big time and this is the worst screw up of all time‚Ä¶ I wish and hope wholeheartedly that the FBI will or is investigating the handling of this case, because that is likely the only way that true Justice will be done for Abby & Libby. I hope they‚Äôre at peace and I hope their families are at peace as well.
